repnme.cdata!:
Estonia - Haapsalu and Matsalu Bays
            Environmental Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The audit concurs with both the
            Implementation Completion Report (ICR) and Evaluation
            Summary (ES) ratings of satisfactory project outcome, likely
            sustainability, and substantial institutional development
            impacts, as well as the satisfactory ratings for both
            performances by the Bank, and Borrower. Lessons suggest that
            for regionally-sponsored environmental initiatives,
            responsive to inter-governmental action plans, provide good
            opportunities for the Bank to exercise its comparative
            advantage in leveraging institutional reform through
            targeted lending, and, if linked with grant funding from
            bilateral development partners, it fosters a powerful, and
            influential lobby for reform. Moreover, significant benefits
            can be achieved through a careful project design that
            addresses infrastructure investments, environmental
            management activities, and capacity building in an
            integrated manner, where multiplier effects will be
            achieved, supportive of local institutions, and their human
            resources development. However, it is important to
            understand the interests, and institutional capabilities of
            local stakeholders, specifically for community based
            activities, and to factor in sufficient time, and resources
            to build a consensus for reform, and agreement on long-term objectives.

repnme.cdata!: Estonia - Haapsalu Matsalu Bays Environment Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project is
            satisfactory, sustainability is likely, and the
            institutional development impact is substantial. Lessons
            emphasize that the cooperative planning, and implementation
            of the project - based on mutual trust between the Bank, and
            Borrower - allowed the transfer of new ideas, and approaches
            to project planning, and management, as well as for
            supporting infrastructure investments. This was conducive to
            a shift from a "reactive", to a
            "proactive" approach, in the development of the
            strategic plan for the Haapsalu Veevark, and the management
            plan for the Matsalu State nature reserve. Additionally, the
            integration of targeted infrastructure investments (focused
            primarily on water, and wastewater services improvement in
            urban areas), but with broader environmental goals,
            successfully achieved the selected environmental management
            activities in adjacent coastal areas, which allowed
            collection, treatment, and disposal of wastewaters to be
            linked with an improved coastal management, and,
            strengthened as well, the management of protected areas. The
            suitability of the participatory approach during the initial
            project implementation, supported by the environmental
            management component, not only increased ownership among
            local communities, and stakeholders in the management of
            protected areas, but the skills gained through these
            participatory activities, can be widely applied in
            environmental development measures. Finally, the project
            demonstrated the beneficial aspects of adjusting project
            objectives, to comply with international environmental
            agreements, namely the Helsinki Convention on Protection of
            Baltic Marine Environment, the Ramsar Convention, and,
            further enhanced the accession process to the European Union.

5082583.majtheme: Urban development,Environment and natural resource management

repnme.cdata!:
Estonia - Haapsalu and Matsalu Bays
            Environment Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Haapsalu and Matsalu Bays
            Environment Project will be implemented over four years as
            an environmental management project for the coastal area of
            western Estonia. It will consist of a Water and Wastewater
            Improvement Component (WWIC) and an Environmental Management
            Component (EMC). The WWIC will consist of: a) rehabilitation
            and expansion of the Haapsalu water and wastewater system,
            including equipment and works along with engineering
            services; and b) institutional strengthening and training to
            assist in establishing an autonomous and financially
            independent water and wastewater utility in Haapsalu. This
            will include assistance for tariff restructuring/tariff
            planning and financial operations. The EMC will consist of:
            a) technical and financial support through the Ministry of
            Environment (MOE) for the implementation of selected
            elements of the Management Plan for Matsalu State Nature
            Reserve by coordinating and providing funding for identified
            investments such as access roads, observation towers, and
            information boards; b) design and implementation of a
            program of cost-effective activities to reduce point and
            non-point source pollution of Matsalu Bay from small
            settlements and agriculture; and c) support for planning and
            management of eco-tourism.

Estonia - Haapsalu and Matsalu Bays
            Environment Project
